subject: Home & DIY
title: The Rule of Thirds in Room Layout
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Rule of Thirds in Room Layout.

hook.text: Photographers use the rule of thirds to compose shots. Interior designers use it to arrange furniture.

buildup.text: Divide your room into a 3Ã—3 grid. Place key furniture at the intersections rather than dead center.

discovery.text: Off-center placement creates visual tension that feels dynamic and interesting, while centering feels static and dull.

twist.text: A sofa slightly off-center with asymmetric art above looks intentional. Dead-center looks like you gave up.

climax.text: Designers break symmetry on purpose, then balance it with a lamp or plant on the lighter side. Controlled asymmetry.

punchline.text: Off-center feels more alive than centered.

quiz.question: What does the rule of thirds suggest about furniture placement?
options: Place key pieces at grid intersections, not dead center
Use exactly three pieces of furniture per room
